question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be sure to ensure that the code you generate is executable for demonstration. I want to create an application that can remove watermarks from images, with the ability to either freely select areas or automatically detect areas for removal. Please provide me with code that I can use on both computer and mobile devices, with responsive design that adapts to different screen sizes.

checklist.title: Core Image Processing Implementation
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code properly implements fundamental image processing techniques for watermark removal, including algorithms such as inpainting, exemplar-based texture synthesis, or frequency domain filtering. Check if the implementation allows for adjusting parameters to handle different types of watermarks (semi-transparent, opaque, pattern-based).0 points if basic image processing is missing, 5 points if only simple opacity-based removal is implemented, 10 points for comprehensive multi-technique approach with parameter adjustments.

checklist.title: Area Selection Mechanisms
checklist.description: Review the implementation of both manual selection tools (rectangular, lasso, polygon) and automatic watermark detection algorithms. Check if the manual selection includes precision tools like edge refinement and feathering controls. Verify that automatic detection can handle common watermark types through methods like frequency analysis or pattern recognition.Deduct 5 points if only rectangular selection is available, 3 points if automatic detection is unreliable across different image types. Full 10 points requires both flexible manual selection and effective automatic detection.

checklist.title: Preview and Comparison Features
checklist.description: Assess whether the application provides real-time or near-real-time preview of watermark removal results, and includes before/after comparison tools. Check for features like split-screen view, opacity slider for comparison, and zoom capabilities to examine details.Deduct 5 points if preview is only available after processing, 3 points if comparison tools are limited. Give 10 points for interactive, real-time preview with comprehensive comparison features.

checklist.title: Cross-platform Responsiveness
checklist.description: Evaluate if the implementation truly works across desktop and mobile platforms with appropriate UI adjustments. Check if the code uses responsive design principles, touch-friendly controls for mobile, and maintains functionality across different screen sizes and input methods.Deduct 5 points if mobile experience is significantly compromised, 3 points if desktop-specific features don't gracefully degrade on smaller screens. Award 10 points for seamless experience across all device types.

checklist.title: Code Robustness
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle edge cases like extremely large images, unusual formats, memory constraints, and browser limitations. Check for graceful degradation when optimal performance isn't possible.Evaluate whether the code handles common abnormal situations (such as invalid images, memory overflow, browser compatibility issues) and provides friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Innovative Features
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. AI-assisted watermark type detection 2. Batch processing capabilities 3. History of edits with non-destructive workflow 4. Export with metadata preservation).Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Feature Relevance and Optimization
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar removal algorithms 2. Function modules unrelated to image processing (e.g., excessive social sharing features) 3. Memory-intensive features that affect performance on mobile devices.Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Engineering Quality
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating processing logic/UI/state management), lazy loading of heavy resources, and code reusability.Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if heavy processing isn't handled with workers or async operations. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Interface Design Quality
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size â‰¥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times) 4) Clear indication of processing status and progress.Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Interaction Experience
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Processing feedback with visual progress indicators 2) Smooth transitions between states (selection to processing to result) 3) Intuitive controls with appropriate touch targets for mobile.Deduct 5 points for operations without feedback, 3 points for laggy responses during image processing, and 5 points for hard-to-find key function buttons. The full score is 10 points.
